channel.title: Practical Networking playing with Hugo
channel.description: Recent content on Practical Networking playing with Hugo

item.title: Symmetric Encryption
item.description: openssl encryption Encryption Openssl can be used for Symmetric Encryption: echo Hello | openssl enc Nothing happened because an algorithm wasnâ€™t specified List all possible algorithms using -list: echo Hello | openssl enc -list Encrypting with AES-128: echo Hello | openssl enc -aes-128-cbc Password requested because Symmetric Encryption requires Secret Key Provide Password in Command echo Hello | openssl enc -aes-128-cbc -pass pass:SECRETKEY On versions of OpenSSL after 1.0, you get this ominous warning: *** WARNING : deprecated key derivation used.

item.title: Playing With Rsa
item.description: Generate RSA Keys: openssl genrsa -out rsa1key.pem 2048 Extract Public Key: openssl rsa -in rsa1key.pem -pubout > rsa1pub.pem openssl pkey -in rsa3key.pem -pubout > rsa1pub.pem Create Cleartext Messages: echo “Attack at Dawn.” > message.txt for msg in {1..100}; do echo “Attack at Dawn! $msg” » bigmessage100.txt; done Encrypt with Public Key: openssl rsautl -encrypt -inkey rsa1pub.pem -pubin -in message.txt -out message.txt.ENC openssl pkeyutl -encrypt -inkey rsa1pub.pem -pubin -in message.txt -out message.

item.title: First Post
item.description: This is the first post on my test blog I’m going to use it to play with Hugo Here is an H2 header This is bold text, and italic text, or maybe italic text. I can also crossout, I think, and maybe underline. This is inline code using backticks. This is triple backtics to create, what I hope becomes a code block with preformatted text allowed More H2 headers Now let’s play with block quotes:
